Fiction

I am the 'book murderer', but I tear them apart out of love

Twitter has taken umbrage at my habit of chopping books into smaller units. But isn’t the real violence against culture happening elsewhere?

Alex Christofi

Alex Christofi is an editor and author of two novels

Wed 22 Jan 2020 11.20 GMT Last modified on Mon 27 Jan 2020 13.38 GMT

  • Share on Facebook
  • Share on Twitter
  • Share via Email
Shares
331
331

Comments

306

We should never bisect the things we love. Friends, nations, puppies. I would argue an exception for pizza. But over the last 24 hours I have found that almost everyone on the internet agrees we should not chop books in half, even if they are very long.

It started when my colleague saw half a paperback on my desk and called me a “book murderer”. I had been enjoying it so much at home that I found the end of a 16-page section, chopped off the remaining pages, bound the unread half in some cardboard to prevent the pages getting too dog-eared, and brought them to work in my pocket. I thought my colleague was overreacting, but when I posted a picture of my latest victims on Twitter, it started trending next to Jess Phillips – who had real news to share. People were replying in other languages, copying in the International Criminal Court, the FBI and the Metropolitan police. Others suggested chopping me in half.

The thing is, I used to think I didn’t like long books. But then I realised that I just didn’t like carrying them around or holding them open with one tired thumb, squashed into someone’s armpit on the tube in rush hour. I did have a Kindle, and I sometimes listened to audiobooks, but whenever I had a big paperback I would leave it at home unread, or struggle through eight pages a night before falling asleep.

So a few years ago, I started seeking out beautiful old two-volume editions of books such as The Brothers Karamazov and War and Peace, which fit neatly in my pocket. I found that I actually read the books that way. I started chopping big paperbacks by modern authors in half and shoddily patching them up. I assumed the authors wouldn’t mind selling a new paperback to someone else, and I really only wanted to get the words into my skull.

Although the majority of the responses were urging me to get in the bin or the sea, I was strangely heartened that people care so much. How amazing that we still value books when so much else is digital or disposable. People never really throw books away. Instead they hand them around, leave them in book exchanges, trade them secondhand, give them to charity, or lend them to friends and relatives. They are the lifeblood of society.

The history of the book, from Gilgamesh to now – books podcast

Listen

It’s tragic when books are used as trays for a restaurant bill, or bought in bulk to give a pop of colour to someone’s interior design. But the real tragedy is that those books aren’t being read. The codex is just a mortal husk – the soul of a book is the story, and the form of words used to tell it. Authors don’t generally dream of seeing their books cellophaned in mint condition, like Star Wars memorabilia. The biggest compliment you can pay an author is to read their book, let them tell you their story – take it to heart and tell others. So I don’t like to think of myself as a book murderer. More like a gung-ho reader. And if you find one of my (short) books in your possession, you have my permission to chop it in half.

  • alexito
    22 Jan 2020 12:07
    72 73

    I once worked in a bookshop ripping the covers off thousands of unsold return books. The covers would be posted back to the publisher in exchange for credit as the books themselves were too heavy to make posting them worthwhile.
    As a result, we were left with several binbags full of jacketless paperbacks. Charity shops weren't interested in taking them, and neither was the local paper recycling firm. It was winter, so I carried a couple of sacks home, stacked the books by the fireplace and tossed a few on when the fire got going. They burned wonderfully, giving a welcoming and distinctly literate blaze of around 451 Fahrenheit.
    The problem was, all my guests accused me of being a Nazi. I pointed out that I clearly wasn't burning the books because of the decadent Jewish nature of their content, but was in fact recycling them and saving them from becoming landfill, but that didn't stop their discomfort. I offered them as many books to take home as they wanted, but it turns out they didn't want jacketless copies of A Year In Provence or Nigel SLater's Real Fast Food , although these are apparently still too sacred to burn.
    On one occasion I felt a pang of guilt as I found myself about to throw a volume of Freud on the fire. But then I opened it and discovered it was, in fact, decadent filth, so on it went.

    • Altarboy Koname Hoten

      9 10

      As you say, it's MY book and I can do what I like with it. No-one said anything about anyone else thinking the same. I bought it expressly for the purpose or chopping into manageable chunks. Second-hand, too, if I remember correctly. 50p-odd.

      And re family/friends, do what I do: if you enjoy a book, buy another copy or copies for other people you think might like it. When books are no longer wanted, give to a charity shop. If a book is in too poor condition for a charity shop, drop it in the compost. All ways of disposal are useful.

      A lot of the weirdness about this debate is how people think their own choices are being infringed, or that they think their status as a book lover is somehow enhanced because they regularly polish the covers of their old paperbacks. I read >75 books a year in all formats, I give a lot away, I buy extras for friends, and destroy almost none. But I don't think destroying a book in order to read it is a hate crime.

      It's not as if books are still produced by monks carefully transcribing every letter in a dark cloister. The material production costs of a book are next to nothing. Surplus books that the bookshops can't sell are pulped back into recycled paper. Read the contents, don't fetishize the object.

    • AngrySkeptic Altarboy

      2 3

      How very wrong you are! Although most books have no instrinsic value as objects (and an even greater number have content of no value) there are some fine editions of titles that are as precious to their owners as a fine vase or other object viewed as "art". An elegant type in a block that is placed exactly right on pages of excellent quality paper, well sewn into a beautiful binding is a work of art to be treasured and enjoyed as an object. I have several volumes that fall into this category. Most are the products of fine presses, but some are trade products that were given special treatment, such as a surprising illustrated cloth binding hidden beneath a regular dust jacket. Much late C19th and early C20th fiction is largely unreadable nonsense now, but the volumes are worth their shelf space because of their glorious cloth bindings.

    • AngrySkeptic Melmouth
      24 Jan 2020 17:37
      0 1

      Here is what I wrote. Please follow along.

      Even book lovers have to discard some of their books. They age and fall to pieces. Do you keep all your empty wine bottles? No. when empty, they are no longer useful.

      Not just old books, but books that fall to pieces with age. Paperbacks are very fond of doing this. This is the comparison with empty wine bottles. The meaning (as you need to have things spelled out for you) is that you ought to discard what is no longer useful or usable. A pile of loose pages is no longer a "book". You might keep if it is in some way essential to you and cannot be replaced with a better copy or a different edition. You might also keep it, if it happens to contain marginal notes by someone important, in which case it becomes a unique object and no longer just a book.

      Books can also lose their value, as their contents become outdated. Why hang on to them. Throw them out, like you would an old matress.

      This speaks for itself. If the content is outdated (e.g. a textbook on astronomy published in the 1920s) it is not useful either to you or to anyone else. It is of value only in a collection on the history of astronomy. Most personal libraries are not so specialised. Some are, of course; a University College professor collected first editions of Darwin in all languages. I saw the collection in the middle 1960s. In this instance it is obviously paramount never to discard a volume, as the integrity of the collection is important.

      You might feel the same way about an outdated book in your collection, so you would probably offer it to a library, preferably a specialising library; but you should know that libraries, between them, make sure to keep a few copies of every title and that they are usually available through the interlibrary loan system, or you could arrange for access to it at one of the country's copyright libraries. I am not certain of the name of a popular novel (Forever Amber I think it was) that had long been out of print, but remained in demand; there was only a single copy of it in all of the UK, in pieces, and it circulated across the country in heavy rubber bands. Most books are not of that kind and they are pulped in their thousands by publishers, booksellers, and libraries. No need for undue sentimentality, of which there is altogether too much in all areas of life.

      Get it now? If you (and those who agree with you) need further clarification, I shall be happy to oblige as long as the Guardian permits.

      However, I came to realise that there really was no point in having and holding shelves and shelves of books which I was never going to read again. I read a lot, so I fill up shelves quickly. We have had a massive clear out, to charity shops, keeping only books that had some special, usually sentimental value. I only read books electronically now, again, with a few exceptions, particularly illustrated or otherwise beautiful books. I love my e-reader and don't miss having the physical books at all. Could I cut a book up? I honestly don't know, because I don't read that way any more.

      This is a choice on my part and I recognise that it isn't for everybody. But I have been heavily criticised by friends whose taste is different to mine, who love the physical book and feel the need to try to persuade me that I am missing out.

      This is the point of my post - read however you want to read, but don't criticise others because they choose to read differently.

  • Ghost36
    22 Jan 2020 12:02
    15 16

    It seems a bit odd to me but the objective seems to me to make it easier for this person to be able to enjoy the books they have bought while they are on the move. It's not like they are going into libraries with a samurai sword - they bought these books and if bisecting them makes it easier for them to read and enjoy them, that's fair enough.

    That said I'm not surprised this has had the reaction it has, especially online. People on the internet are incredibly precious about physical printed books.

    I get it, to a certain extent - who doesn't like a nice book? That's the reason I own several copies of Dracula; as a favourite of mine, I can't resist buying any time I see a nice-looking version.

    But to get so incredibly worked up - as if what makes a book precious and important is the paper it's printed on or the ink it is printed with, and not the words and the ideas and emotions they communicate - is a particularly 'online' thing. I wonder if it is perhaps a sense of resistance; that because people are using something as ephemeral as social media to communicate, they feel the need to extol an almost obsessive valuing of physical, printed books as a sort of counterweight?

    That or they are just the sort of tiresome bores who think a person's worth and intellect is measured by how many books they have on the shelves in their home, and so have come to fetishise the book as an object, rather than for what it can bring them when read.

    About two hundred million books produced each year in the UK. What do people think must happen to most of them? I remember reading many years ago of the paperbacks that would be distributed to small newsagents to stand in a rotary display unit for a couple of months. Then the unsold ones would be replaced with a new batch. And where did the unsold paperbacks go:-

    "The new M6 toll road has been built on two and a half million copies of old Mills & Boon novels to prevent it from cracking.
    Unsold copies of the books were shredded into a paste and added to a mixture of asphalt and Tarmac. It helps to bind the asphalt and the Tarmac, preventing the surface from splitting apart after heavy use.
    The construction company responsible for laying the road, Tarmac Central, used 92,000 books per mile for a 16-mile stretch of the road and said it should ensure the motorway remained free of roadworks. Richard Beal, project manager, said that Mills & Boon novels were used because millions are returned to the factory each year unsold." (Telegraph, 18/12/03)

    Anyone read The Book of Sand by Jorge Luis Borges, about an infinite book? Good luck trying to split that book down.

    Ironically, Borges one of the most erudite minds of all time didn't have a high opinion of long books.

    “Writing long books is a laborious and impoverishing act of foolishness: expanding in five hundred pages an idea that could be perfectly explained in a few minutes. A better procedure is to pretend that those books already exist and to offer a summary, a commentary.”

A perennial underachiever, Jorge Luis Borges only ever managed to write many of the best short stories of all time.
